title: Taiwan Battery-Swapping Pioneer Gogoro to Go Public in SPAC Merger; Taipei-based company said it plans to list on the Nasdaq Stock Market
text:
Gogoro will raise net proceeds of up to $550 million in the deal, stemming from $345 million raised in Poema's offering earlier this year and $250 million from a so-called PIPE, or private investment in public equity. The PIPE funding round, which is typical in SPAC mergers, includes backing from Taiwan electronics giant Foxconn Technology Group, Singaporean sovereign-wealth fund Temasek Holdings, Indonesia tech company GoTo Group and Generation Investment Management, a sustainable investment firm co-founded by former U.S. Vice President Al Gore.

Gogoro expects the deal to close in the first quarter of 2022 and it will trade under the ticker symbol GGR.

Founded in 2011, Gogoro makes electric scooters, batteries and networks of vending machine-sized battery stations where drivers can swap out depleted batteries for fresh ones. In Taiwan, where its batteries power the vast majority of all electric two-wheelers, the company operates a network of more than 2,100 battery-swapping stations that are paired with convenience stores, supermarkets, coffee shops and other venues.

Gogoro is betting on rising demand from consumers and policy makers in congested urban areas for electric two-wheelers and also for battery-swapping systems that work across brands and offer a speedier alternative to charge-based systems. Its early backers include Temasek, Mr. Gore's firm, Panasonic Corp., Sumitomo Corp., France's Engie SA and others.

"We firmly believe that electric mobility adoption is inevitable," Chief Executive Horace Luke, a former executive at Microsoft Corp. and Taiwanese smartphone maker HTC Corp., said in an interview. "This decade is the beginning of it all."

The company plans to use proceeds from the deal to export its battery-swapping infrastructure and other technology to China, India and parts of Southeast Asia.

Later this year, Gogoro plans to begin providing battery-swapping infrastructure for a range of two-wheel vehicles being developed in China by motorcycle maker Dachangjiang Group and Yadea Group, one of the world's top manufacturers of electric scooters.

It also has plans with Hero MotoCorp, the world's largest maker of motorcycles and scooters, to develop a Hero-brand electric vehicle and build a network of battery-swapping stations in India.

Gogoro reported revenue of about $364 million last year. It expects that to rise to $500 million next year and $1.7 billion in 2024 as its tie-ups in China and India take shape. Its debt stood at about $518 million at the end of June, the company said.

Poema is affiliated with Princeville Capital, a climate- and technology-focused growth-equity firm that counts actor Leonardo DiCaprio among its advisers and investors.

Write to Ben Otto at ben.otto@wsj.com

Taiwan Battery-Swapping Pioneer Gogoro to Go Public in SPAC Merger
